newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks open stronger, record beckons.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks open stronger, record beckons.

text.p: Australian shares opened stronger on Monday after record highs reached in New York and London and firmer base metal prices on the London Metal Exchange.
After one hour of trade the All Ordinaries index was 18.2 points higher at 2,333.7, within striking range of its record high of 2350.1 set on February 3, 1994.
But trading was quiet due to the Labour Day holiday in New South Wales, Australian Capital Territory and South Australia.
Traders said the holiday was likely to subdue trading but the market was likely to hold its gains for the rest of the day.
"It has had a good kick start to the day," said a Perth broker. "Generally it should be pretty firm, in line with the experiences in New York and London on Friday," he said.
Rises were across the board in both industrial and resource issues, with only the chemical sector going against the rising trend. Rises outnumbered falls by a ratio of about four-to-one.
CRA recorded the largest turnover, representing nearly A$100 million (US$79 million) or about 40 percent of the value of the first hour's total business.
The Anglo-Australian miner and fellow mining gaint BHP were the biggest risers among the blue chips in morning trade.
CRA was up 20 cents at A$19.45 while BHP was up 18 cents at A$16.62.
